studies.title: Metabolism links nutrient stress and harmful algal bloom formation
studies.description: Four species of phytoplankton representing important bloom-forming species from three globally important phyla (Bacillariophyta, Haptophyta, and Ochrophyte) were cultured in this study. These species include the cosmopolitan diatom Chaetoceros affinis CCMP159 (isolated from Great South Bay, NY, USA, 1958), the haptophytes Chrysochromulina polylepis CCMP1757 (isolated from the North Sea 1988) and Gephyrocapsa oceanica RCC1303 (isolated from Arachon Bay, France, Jan 1999), and the raphidophyte Heterosigma akashiwo strain CCMP 2393 (isolated from Rehoboth Bay, Delaware, USA). Cultures were grown under three conditions: nitrogen-stress, phosphorus-stress, and replete conditions. Intracellular metabolites were extracted from cultures and analyzed with targeted and untargeted mass spectrometry-based metabolomics methods.

publications.title: Harmful Algal Bloom-Forming Organism Responds to Nutrient Stress Distinctly From Model Phytoplankton
publications.authorList: McLean Craig, Haley Sheean T., Swarr Gretchen J., Soule Melissa C. Kido, Dyhrman Sonya T., Kujawinski Elizabeth B.

publications.title: Prostaglandins Indicate P-Stress within Blooming Diatoms in Narragansett Bay
publications.authorList: McLean, Craig, Harriet Alexander, Sheean T. Haley, Melissa C. Kido-Soule, Krista Longnecker, Gretchen J. Swarr, Sonya T. Dyhrman and Elizabeth B. Kujawinski

publications.title: Stress Response Archetypes Distinguish Phytoplankton Groups
publications.authorList: McLean, Craig, G. Leventhal, Gretchen J. Swarr, Melissa C. Kido Soule, Sonya T. Dyhrman and Elizabeth B. Kujawinski

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Culture Maintenance:

4 species of phytoplankton representing important bloom-forming species from 3 globally important phyla (Bacillariophyta, Haptophyta, and Ochrophyte) in this study were cultured. These species include the cosmopolitan diatom Chaetoceros affinis CCMP159 (isolated from Great South Bay, NY, USA, 1958), the haptophytes Chrysochromulina polylepis CCMP1757 (isolated from the North Sea 1988) and Gephyrocapsa oceanica RCC1303 (isolated from Arachon Bay, France, Jan 1999), and the raphidophyte Heterosigma akashiwo strain CCMP 2393 (isolated from Rehoboth Bay, Delaware, USA). All species with the exception of G. oceanica were cultured in modified L1 medium made with autoclaved 0.2-μm filtered seawater from Vineyard Sound, MA with the following nitrogen to phosphorus ratio: replete (576 mM NaNO3, 36.2 mM NaH2PO4), N-stress (5 µM NaNO3 and 36.2 µM NaH2PO4), and P-stress (5 µM NaNO3 and 0.2 µM NaH2PO4). G. oceanica was cultured at the following nitrogen to phosphorus ratio: replete (100 µM NaNO3 and 6 µM NaH2PO4), N-stress (1 µM NaNO3 and 6 µM NaH2PO4), and P-stress (100 µM NaNO3 and no added NaH2PO4). The lower nutrient concentrations for G. oceanica are necessary to ensure consistent calcification. Each culture was grown with light intensity of 100 μmol quanta/m^2/s of photosynthetically active radiation (400-700 nm) during a 14 h:10 h light:dark cycle and temperature varied by species (according to species-specific temperature preferences) with C. affinis, G. oceanica, and H. akashiwo grown at 18 °C, and C. polylepis grown at 15 °C. Some cultures were continuously rotated on an orbital shaker (H. akashiwo, 75 rpm; C. affinis, 100 rpm; C. polylepis, 100 rpm) to maintain optimal growth. Cultures were not axenic, but were uni-algal and uni-eukaryotic.


Experimental Design:

Entrainment cultures were used to initiate experimental cultures to decrease carryover of nutrients from stock cultures and promote acclimation to the experimental conditions. Single entrainment cultures (~100 ml) were grown in modified L1 medium (base seawater as above) under the following nitrogen to phosphorus ratios: replete (samples with 'R' in sample names, 576 µM NaNO3 and 36.2 µM NaH2PO4), N-stress (samples with 'N' in sample names, 5 µM NaNO3 and 36.2 µM NaH2PO4), and P-stress (cells with 'P' in sample names, 5 µM NaNO3 and 0.2 µM NaH2PO4). Entrainment cultures were kept at 18 °C on a 14 h:10 h light:dark cycle (as above) with gentle rotation (75 rpm) for 3 d. We initiated experiments by inoculating triplicate 1-L flasks (containing 0.3 L media) for each treatment with 30 ml of the corresponding entrainment culture and maintained the replicate flasks under the same conditions as the entrainment cultures.


Growth was monitored in each flask by in vivo chlorophyll fluorescence on a Turner Designs Aquafluor handheld fluorometer with paired cell counts. Cell count samples were preserved in 2% (final concentration) acid Lugol's solution and cell concentrations were determined by microscopic counts. Measurements were recorded at the same time each day (during the middle of the light phase) to avoid diel changes in metabolite synthesis. Replete cultures were harvested in exponential phase, and harvested N-stress and P-stress cultures once growth rates and cell yields were reduced relative to the replete control, in agreement with the definition of nutrient stress rather than deficiency[1]. Filtered cells (300 ml) of each replicate in each treatment were filtered onto combusted 47 mm GF/Fs (Whatman) using combusted glass filtration funnels under low vacuum pressure (never exceeding 5 mm Hg) to collect particulate metabolite samples. Filters were flash-frozen in cryovials in liquid nitrogen and then stored -80 °C until extraction.


Ref:

[1] MacIntyre HL, JJ Cullen. 2005 Using cultures to investigate the physiological ecology of microalgae.

In R.A. Andersen (Ed.), Algal Culturing Techniques (pp. 287-326): Academic Press.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Each filter was split in half for separate extractions for targeted and untargeted metabolomic analysis. The extraction procedure for untargeted and targeted samples was identical with the exception of the final solid phase extraction (see below). For both types of analyses, each filter was first cut into 6 roughly equivalent pieces which were then weighed. The weight was used to determine the fraction of the obtained filtered volume for each sample. The filter pieces were placed within an 8 ml amber glass vial. Metabolites were extracted from filters using cold 40:40:20 acetonitrile:methanol:water+0.1 M formic acid similar to previous work[1]. 25 µl of 1 µg/ml deuterated standard mix (d3-glutamic acid, d4-4-hydroxybenzoic acid, and d5-taurocholate) was then added as extraction recovery standards. The solvent-filter mixture was sonicated for 10 min to lyse the cells, and the solvent was then transferred into a microcentrifuge tube. The filters were rinsed with 3 x 200 µl aliquots of extraction solvent to capture any remaining organic matter. The combined extracts were centrifuged at 20,000 x g for 5 min, and the supernatant carefully decanted into new 8 ml amber glass vials to leave behind any scraps of filter or cellular detritus. The solvents were neutralized with 25.6 μl of 6 M ammonium hydroxide and subsequently dried down in a vacufuge. For targeted analysis, dried samples were neutralized in 95:5 water:acetonitrile solution plus 2.5 μl of 5 μg/ml deuterated standard mix.


Due to the sensitivity of untargeted analyses to high salt concentrations, solid-phase extraction was used as an additional desalting step. These samples were reconstituted with 500 μl of 0.05 μg/ml biotin D2 with 0.01 M HCl to lower the pH to 2 and ran these samples through 100 mg of 1 ml­Agilent Bond Elut PPL cartridges. The cartridge was pre-conditioned with 1 bed-volume of 100% methanol. Acidified untargeted samples were run through the cartridge at a flow rate no greater than 40 ml/min. The cartridges were rinsed with 1 bed-volume of 0.01 M HCl, then dried down for 5 min, and the metabolites eluted with 8 ml of methanol. Untargeted samples were dried again and brought up to 250 µL with 95:5 water:acetonitrile in new vials plus 2.5 µl of 5 µg/ml deuterated standard mix. 45 µl from each sample was combined to create a pooled sample.


Ref:

[1] Rabinowitz JD, Kimball E. Acidic acetonitrile for cellular metabolome extraction from Escherichia coli. Anal Chem. 2007 Aug 15;79(16):6167-73. doi:10.1021/ac070470c. PMID:17630720.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
For untargeted analysis, high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Micro AS autosampler and Surveyor MS Pump Plus, Thermo Scientific) was used to separate metabolites on a Synergi Fusion reverse phase C18 column (4 µm, 2.0 x 150 mm, Phenomenex), equipped with a guard column and precolumn filter, and maintained at 35 °C. The column was eluted with (A) 0.1% formic acid in water and (B) 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile at a flow rate of 0.25 ml/min. The column was held at 5% B for 2 min, ramped to 65% B over 18 min, quickly ramped to 100% B in 5 min, held at 100% B for 7 min and then equilibrated at 5% B for 8 min prior to the next injection (total run time = 40 min). 20 µl sample was injected individually for positive and negative ion mode analyses.


For targeted analysis, ultra-performance liquid chromatography (UPLC, Accela Open Autosampler and Accela 1250 Pump, Thermo Scientific) coupled to a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (TSQ Vantage, Thermo Scientific) was used for chromatographic separation performed on a Waters Acquity HSS T3 column (2.1 x 100 mm, 1.8 μm) equipped with a Vanguard pre-column and maintained at 40 °C. The column was eluted with (A) 0.1% formic acid in water and (B) 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min.The gradient starts at 1% B for 1 min, ramp to 15% B from 1-3 min, ramp to 50% from 3-6 min, ramp to 95% B from 6-9 min, hold until 10 min, ramp to 1% from 10-10.2 min, and a final hold at 1% B (total gradient time 12 min).

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description:
For untargeted analysis, a hybrid linear ion trap-Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance (FT-ICR) mass spectrometer (7T LTQ FT Ultra, Thermo Scientific) was used. The mass spectrometer was externally calibrated weekly in positive and negative modes using the manufacturer's solutions. The capillary temperature was optimized and ESI voltage at 330 °C and 4.2 kV in positive mode and at 365 °C and 3.8 kV in negative mode. Sheath gas, auxiliary gas, and sweep gas flow rates were maintained at 35, 5, and 2, respectively (arbitrary units) for both polarities. High resolution MS and data dependent MS/MS scans were collected as follows: (1) a full MS scan in the FT-ICR analyzer from 100-1000 m/z, with mass resolving power set to 100,000 (defined at m/z 400); and (2) collision-induced dissociation fragmentation scans (MS/MS) in the linear ion trap for the 4 most abundant ions in each full scan. MS/MS spectra were collected under dynamic exclusion with an exclusion time of 20 s. The pooled sample was injected multiple times prior to running the samples to condition the column with the sample matrix to stabilize peak retention times. Pooled samples to be used for quality assurance were also run prior to and after our set of 9 samples.


Targeted samples were analyzed by ultra-performance liquid chromatography (UPLC, Accela Open Autosampler and Accela 1250 Pump, Thermo Scientific) coupled via heated electrospray ionization (H-ESI) to a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (TSQ Vantage, Thermo Scientific) operated under selected reaction monitoring (SRM) mode. The spray voltage was set at 4000 V (positive mode) and 3200 V (negative mode). Source gases were set at 55 (sheath) and 20 (aux gas), heated capillary temperature at 375 °C, and the vaporizer temperature at 400 °C. Separate 5 μl autosampler injections were made for positive and negative ion modes.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
Untargeted data files were converted from proprietary Thermo RAW into XML-based mzML format using msConvert[1]. These files were processed using XCMS and AutoTuner[2]-[4]. Processing returned a spreadsheet of features. Features were defined as peaks with unique mass to charge (m/z) and retention time values, with relative abundances determined by their area. Processed data was subjected to quality control filtering by removing possible contaminants and non-reproducible features as described previously[5]. Briefly, features observed within blanks, features with a coefficient of variation higher than 0.2 within pooled samples, and features with low reproducibility across factor groups were removed. From day 3, metabolite concentrations normalized by the cell counts were reported.


MAVEN was used to integrate compound peak areas within targeted data[6]. An in-house MATLAB script was used to apply quality control filtering and to quantify peak areas using a standard curve made up of 4 to 10 points. Metabolites were retained for this analysis if (1) the peak included a confirm ion, and (2) the metabolite was present within 2 out of 3 biological replicates of each treatment. The list was further culled by correcting for metabolite presence in procedural blanks. Compound ion suppression was estimated as the intensity ratio between a 500 ng/ml standard mix dissolved in Milli-Q water and the matching standard mix dissolved in pooled sample matrix. All concentrations are given as attomole per cell.


Refs:

[1] Chambers MC, Maclean B, Burke R, Amodei D, Ruderman DL, Neumann S, Gatto L et al. A cross-platform toolkit for mass spectrometry and proteomics. Nat Biotechnol. 2012 Oct;30(10):918-20. doi:10.1038/nbt.2377. PMID:23051804.

[2] McLean C, Kujawinski EB. AutoTuner: High Fidelity and Robust Parameter Selection for Metabolomics Data Processing. Anal Chem. 2020 Apr 21;92(8):5724-5732. doi:10.1021/acs.analchem.9b04804. PMID: 32212641.

[3] Smith CA, Want EJ, O'Maille G, Abagyan R, Siuzdak G. XCMS: processing mass spectrometry data for metabolite profiling using nonlinear peak alignment, matching, and identification. Anal Chem. 2006 Feb 1;78(3):779-87. doi:10.1021/ac051437y. PMID:16448051.

[4] Tautenhahn R, Böttcher C, Neumann S. Highly sensitive feature detection for high resolution LC/MS. BMC Bioinformatics. 2008 Nov 28;9:504. doi:10.1186/1471-2105-9-504. PMID:19040729.

[5] Dunn WB, Broadhurst D, Begley P, Zelena E, Francis-McIntyre S, Anderson N, Brown M etal.; Human Serum Metabolome (HUSERMET) Consortium. Procedures for large-scale metabolic profiling of serum and plasma using gas chromatography and liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry. Nat Protoc. 2011 Jun 30;6(7):1060-83. doi:10.1038/nprot.2011.335. PMID:21720319.

[6] Melamud E, Vastag L, Rabinowitz JD. Metabolomic analysis and visualization engine for LC-MS data. Anal Chem. 2010 Dec 1;82(23):9818-26. doi:10.1021/ac1021166. PMID:21049934.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
For compounds outside of our existing targeted method[1], authentic standards at the highest grade available were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. Standards were injected at 1 μg/ml concentration in Milli-Q water to optimize selected reaction monitoring (SRM) conditions (s-lens, collision energy, product ions). At least 2 SRM transitions (precursor-product ion pairs) were monitored for quantification and confirmation of each target compound, derived from optimization protocols that maximize analyte signal-to-noise. The expected retention time of each compound was determined with standards dissolved in Milli-Q.


3 compounds cannot be distinguished with our current method and are reported as follows:

- Threonine and homoserine are reported as threonine/homoserine (C4.H9.N.O3)

- Alanine and sarcosine are reported as alanine/sarcosine (C3.H7.N.O2)

- 3-phosphoglyceric acid and 2-phosphoglyceric acid are reported as phosphoglyceric acid (C3.H7.O7.P)


Ref:

[1] Johnson WM, Kido Soule MC, Kujawinski EB (2017). Extraction efficiency and quantification of dissolved metabolites in targeted marine metabolomics. Limnol Oceanogr Methods 15: 417-428.
